1.brief: to exist, i.e. be or become, come to pass (always emphatic, and not a mere copula or auxiliary)
a word; by implication, a matter (as spoken of) or thing; adverbially, a cause
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
near, with or among; often in general, to

2.brief: a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
ruddy i.e. a human being (an individual or the species, mankind, etc.)
to put (used in a great variety of applications, literal, figurative, inferentially, and elliptically)
the face (as the part that turns); used in a great variety of applications (literally and figuratively); also (with prepositional prefix) as a preposition (before, etc.)
near, with or among; often in general, to
Gog, the name of an Israelite, also of some nothern nation
the earth (at large, or partitively a land)
Magog, a son of Japheth; also a barbarous northern region
properly, an exalted one, i.e. a king or sheik; also a rising mist
the head (as most easily shaken), whether literal or figurative (in many applications, of place, time, rank, itc.)
Meshek, a son of Japheth, and the people descended from him
Tubal, a postdiluvian patriarch and his posterity
to prophesy, i.e. speak (or sing) by inspiration (in prediction or simple discourse)
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications

the Lord (used as a proper name of God only)
near, with or among; often in general, to

4.brief: to turn back (hence, away) transitively or intransitively, literally or figuratively (not necessarily with the idea of return to the starting point); generally to retreat; often adverbial, again
to give, used with greatest latitude of application (put, make, etc.)
a ring for the nose (or lips)
the cheek (from its fleshiness); hence, the jaw-bone
to go (causatively, bring) out, in a great variety of applications, literally and figuratively, direct and proxim.
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
probably a force, whether of men, means or other resources; an army, wealth, virtue, valor, strength
a horse (as leaping); also a swallow (from its rapid flight)
a steed (as stretched out to a vehicle, not single nor for mounting ); also (by implication) a driver (in a chariot), i.e. (collectively) cavalry
properly, wrap around, i.e. (by implication) to put on agarment or clothe (oneself, or another), literally or figuratively
perfection (i.e. concrete adverbial, splendidly)
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
assemblage (usually concretely)
abundant (in quantity, size, age, number, rank, quality)
a hook (as pointed); also a (large) shield (as if guarding by prickliness); also cold (as piercing)
a shield (i.e. the small one or buckler); figuratively, a protector; also the scaly hide of the crocodile
to manipulate, i.e. seize; chiefly to capture, wield, specifically, to overlay; figuratively, to use unwarrantably
drought; also a cutting instrument (from its destructive effect), as a knife, sword, or other sharp implement
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)

Cush (or Ethiopia), the name of a son of Ham, and of his territory; also of an Israelite
Put, a son of Ham, also the name of his descendants or their region, and of a Persian tribe
properly, nearness (used only as a preposition or an adverb), near; hence, generally, with, by, at, among, etc.
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
a shield (i.e. the small one or buckler); figuratively, a protector; also the scaly hide of the crocodile

a house (in the greatest variation of applications, especially family, etc.)

who, which, what, that; also (as an adverb and a conjunction) when, where, how, because, in order that, etc.
properly, nearness (used only as a preposition or an adverb), near; hence, generally, with, by, at, among, etc.

23.brief: to be (causatively make) large (in various senses, as in body, mind, estate or honor, also in pride)
to be (causatively, make, pronounce or observe as) clean (ceremonially or morally)

to know (properly, to ascertain by seeing); used in a great variety of senses, figuratively, literally, euphemistically and inferentially (including observation, care, recognition; and causatively, instruction, designation, punishment, etc.)
an eye (literally or figuratively); by analogy, a fountain (as the eye of the landscape)
a foreign nation; hence, a Gentile; also (figuratively) a troop of animals, or a flight of locusts
abundant (in quantity, size, age, number, rank, quality)

to know (properly, to ascertain by seeing); used in a great variety of senses, figuratively, literally, euphemistically and inferentially (including observation, care, recognition; and causatively, instruction, designation, punishment, etc.)
(by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
